author: Scott, Walter
snippet: But though Harden, Alva, andTorwoodlee voted for this measure, it was refused by the rest of themeeting, to my disappointment; since in its present state it will not beattended to, and is in fact too milk-and-water to attract notice.

title: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Volume 6
author: Lockhart, J. G. (John Gibson)
snippet: Torwoodlee, Gala, and I,     have offered to raise a corps, to be called the Loyal Foresters,     to act anywhere south of the Forth.

title: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Volume 6
author: Lockhart, J. G. (John Gibson)
snippet: Theprogress of the western _Reformers_ by degrees led even the mostimportant Whigs in that district to exert themselves in theorganization of volunteer regiments, both mounted and dismounted; and,when it became generally suspected that Glasgow and Paisley maintaineda dangerous correspondence with the refractory colliers ofNorthumberland--Scott, and his friends the Lairds of Torwoodlee andGala, determined to avail themselves of the loyalty and spirit of themen of Ettrick and Teviotdale, and proposed first raising a companyof sharpshooters among their own immediate neighbors, andafterwards--this plan receiving every encouragement--a legion orbrigade upon a large scale, to be called the Buccleuch Legion.

title: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott, Volume 6

snippet: Torwoodlee, Gala, and I,     have offered to raise a corps, to be called the Loyal Foresters,     to act anywhere south of the Forth.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,

snippet: Torwoodlee 1 thought of, when he told me, as I was bragging a little of my plantations, that it would be long ere crows built in them.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: Torwoodlee, Gala, and I, have offered to raise a corps, to be called the Loyal Foresters, to act anywhere south of the Forth.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: Torwoodlee and Gala, determined to avail themselves of the loyalty and spirit of the men of Ettrick and Teviotdale, and proposed first raising a company of sharpshooters among their own immediate neighbours, and afterwards — this plan receiving every encouragement  — a legion or brigade upon a large scale, to be called the Buccleuch Legion.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: Young Walter Scott had been for a year or more Cornet  in the corps, and his father was consulting Torwoodlee  about an entertainment which he meant to give them on his son's approaching birth-day.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: We had another joyous evening at Torwoodlee.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: Next day, accordingly, we all rode over together to Mr. Pringle's beautiful seat — the " distant Torwoodlee " of the Lay of the Last Minstrel, but distant not above five or six miles from Abbotsford — coursing hares as we proceeded, but inspecting the antiquities of the Gatrail to the interruption  of our sport.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: Yonder is Lammermuir, and Smailholme ; and there you have Galashiels, and Torwoodlee, and Gala Water ; and in that direction you see Teviotdale and the Braes of Yarrow, and Ettrick stream winding along like a silver thread, to throw itself into the Tweed.'

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: Torwoodlee, too, and his son the Skipper, came to breakfast to-day, in order that the whole party might have a consultation before going to the railroad meeting at Melrose.

title: Peter's letters to his kinsfolk.
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: To distant Torwoodlee.

title: Abbotsford and Newstead abbey.
author: Irving, Washington
snippet: Among those who occasionally admitted him to this familiarity, was old John Scott of Galla, a man of family, who inhabited his paternal man sion of Torwoodlee.

title: Memorials of his time,
author: Cockburn, Henry Cockburn
snippet: The old laird of Torwoodlee survives to enjoy the reward of his having planted judiciously, in seeing his now beautiful place nearly buried in foliage.

title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: " There is Pringle o' Yair, and Pringle o' Torwoodlee, and Pringle o' Haining—ye may gang tothem and compleen o' the bad roads; but that'snae reason for treadin' down the minister's grass,and that's eneuch."
